reviews.content: Glad I opted for the Bike over the Kickr because it's adjustable to fit both of us. My partner didn't expect to like it as much as they do. It arrived very quickly and was easy to set up with Zwift. The bike sizing app gets you pretty close and just needs a few tweaks to match your real bike setup. Everything seems very strong and well put-together. So far I haven't experienced any problems with the seat post clamp as some other users have. I did change the saddle and bar tape though.

reviews.content:
So far I really love it. 
There’re some things to improve though:
Setting up the saddle height and tightening it is quite awkward. As it is not an outdoor bike, some ratchet mechanism for would have been achievable and appreciated.
The position of the steering buttons is also not the best, as it can be pressed without intention very easily. Also it worked straight away on Zwift but now for some unknown reason it’s no longer working.
But the major drawback in my opinion is that I’ve noticed a quite important lag in the bike adjustment when connected to Zwift of about 5 seconds (maybe more). For that reasons I’ve downgraded the mark by 1 star.
But overall, the pedaling feeling is so smooth that it’s still worth the change from my previous Kickr Core.
Hope this review will be found helpful to all.

reviews.content: The kickr bike has been a revelation. I've graduated from a basic magnetic brake turbo and the difference is remarkable. The feel and responsiveness of the kickr bike mean that I actually now look forward to a "turbo session". If this piece of kit doesn't make me a stronger cyclist nothing will. Highly highly recommend.

Sehr gute Lieferung, der Aufbau kein Problem, Fahren/Training macht richtig Spaß.
Das einzige Manko ist ein leicht schiefer
Vorbau und ein leichtes Knackgeräusch an der Kurbel, dass ich mittlerweile selbst beseitigt habe.
Lenker und Sattel habe ich getauscht, ist aber Geschmackssache und erfordert beim Lenker etwas Handwekliches Geschick ( kurzer Imbusschlüssel )
Ist wie bei einem echten Rad !
Bin sehr begeistert und wurde es jederzeit wieder kaufen. 
Grüße aus dem Taunus 
Olaf

It’s well built. I have replaced the seat with one identical to my bikes.

It does drop out occasionally which has involved a hard reset. Disconnect power. But that’s okay, I won’t be winning any races anytime soon. 
Very quiet. If it wasn’t for my fan, you wouldn’t have to adjust the tv volume. 
Still working out the active part. Seems understated. 
Got it on clearance. Seems great value though the wifi upgrade would be great to stop the drop outs.

The bike came well-packaged and was in no time in my pain cave. The setup was easy together with the Apple TV and Wahoo RGT. There is one single issue during the rides...after some minutes in some situations there is a cracking sound from the height of the crank. I could not figure out, where it comes from but for a product in this price range that shouldn't be.

The bike stands very stable (my weight is 85 kg) and is well build. I have fun go ride it!

reviews.content:
I've been wanting a Kickr bike since the day it was released. Black Friday gave me an excellent opportunity to buy the rather expensive machine. 
The ride feel is absolutely fantastic, can't say anything that really bothers me.
I've had some issues however with the connection to Zwift. During rides I often have to deal with dropouts. I'll make it work eventually but the connection with the Kickr trainer I used before seemed to be more stable.
The seat post clamp is another issue. I have to tighten it really hard for the seat to stay in place. Doing so, my wife is unable to adjust the bike to her standards as she hasn't got the power to loosen it.

reviews.content: Wonderful piece of machinery. The steer / cockpit is not extremely stiff. Feedback (up/downhill), features (gear set simulations - Di2, Campagnolo etc) and adjustments (geometry) you can make are all together such a joy. It’s stable, feels durable and easy to move. If you are on the market for a trainer and not sure you want to put your (spare) bike on a trainer the Kickr Bike is no brainer. BLT Connection to the app (I use RGT) is stable, sometimes I need to connect the bike manually with 2 mouse clicks. Costs 2 seconds. I also recommend the headwind which can be linked to speed/heartrate. I came from a first a gen trainer (Drivo) ;-)
reviews.title: No brainer

reviews.content:
Think hard about whether to buy this. Overall I’m glad I did but only because I got it at the £2199 price. Full price and I’d be ‘no way’ because there are just too many defects. 

Assembly is simple, set up and connection to Zwift is also easy. The problems for me came when I started fitting it and then sitting on it.

The fit via the app is a very good starting point but it needs refining. It suggested for me (I’m 182cm) a saddle height of over 15 on the seatpost. Ok, but the post only goes up to 14. I contacted Wahoo and after supplying details of my fit to check what I was saying was true they told me I needed a larger seatpost which they then sent out to me a few days later. That to me is bonkers. I’m not a giant: why not just include a larger seatpost as standard?

As it happens that was not the only thing they had to send me over the first week or two: I’ve now been sent three quick release levers and an Allen bolt fixing — all to try and fasten the seatpost and the handlebars. They keep slipping. This is a well documented problem: it’s a design fault and the fittings are shoddy. You spend a lot of time emailing wahoo support (which is very responsive) trying to implement what are clearly hacks and workarounds. Their latest is to suggest buying some carbon grip paste. Wow. 

One of the reasons I bought this was so we could easily adjust the fit settings for both my wife and I. There is no way she can open the QR clamps given the force you need to open and close them. 

So why have I kept it? Because once you get past all this, it is (so far) a great great improvement for me on the smart trainer setup I had before (old entry Tiagra set up bike on an Elite Suito). It takes up less space, the feel is way better; weirdly the pedalling feels smoother as well. The tilt function is great and just adds a little variability to alleviate turbo boredom. 

People moan about the gear LED display but it’s not a huge issue. But the gears themselves take some mental adjustment and I think this is partly a result of Wahoo setting expectations too high by claiming you can set them up to relocate your outdoor bike. While you can choose whatever group set you like, be warned: those gears do not feel like you’re riding outdoors. The shift from top few sprockets on the cassette into the bigger gears is really noticeable. Whereas before for sprints I may well have shifted into the 13 or 12 sprocket straight away and stayed there, on this and for whatever set up I choose I never move into the smaller sprockets on the Kickr. I hit the same power as before but it feels harder work. You just have to adjust. Wahoo has provided some explanation around gravity and perception for this change versus outdoors and I get that: but why market it so much that the gearing is a replica of outdoors if they know it’s not really?

Anyway you get used to it. 

I’m two weeks in and I think 4 stars is about right, perhaps 3.5.
reviews.title: Good but some warnings

reviews.content:
This is my first foray into the use of a static bike for fitness and it’s still early days but I’m impressed so far. 
I like that I can set it up to reflect my road bike dimensions and gearing. The supplied saddle and handlebars are comfortable to use but I will change the pedals for something more appropriate.
I had no problem assembling the system and it seems well constructed and robust enough for the tasks ahead. I’ve had a couple of free-form rides and one guided by Wahoo Systm so far. Certainly having the guided ride made the time go quicker and I actually found it easier than the unguided rides.
So far, then, so good!
reviews.title: Impressed so far

reviews.content:
I’m an avid cyclist, and having a quality trainer to use when not out on the roads is more important to me than it’s ever been. I started with a Kickr core 2 years ago, upgraded to a 2018 Kickr 1 year ago for a more stable and accurate sprinting platform, and made the transition to the Kickr Bike last month. Real bike feel is paramount to me. I average 175km indoors and 200km outdoors weekly, the Kickr bike has made the fitting process and adaptability a breeze. No more fiddling with chains and cassettes, no more NOISE, and no more lengthy sweat cleanup sessions. It is sleek, elegant, capable, dynamic, and customizable. I was hesitant to make this investment in a trainer, but so far it has been a joy to have everything WORK and SYNC every time, right away. I verify the wattage through my Assiamo Duo power pedals, and the readings have consistently proven within 1.5%. 
If you train indoors regularly, you should not hesitate to invest in the best; you do outdoors, it only makes sense to do so indoors as well. Looking forward to putting it through it’s paces this ZRL and testing that upper wattage threshold. 

Happy camper. Suffering well. ;)
reviews.title: From Core to Kickr to Kickr Bike

reviews.title: good product ....bad support

set.name: set
set.sentence: easy set up.....I have had to figure out all of it myself because Wahoo support no longer seems to have any phone contact...and the online support is terrible...everything could be so much better if only there was someone who would I could call...about specific issues of connectivity, I recommend the product I am unhappy with support

reviews.content: I am really enjoying my KICKR Bike. The overall experience is quite good. The handlebars and seat are terrible but easy (ish) to replace. My main gripe is the excessive whine and at times jerkiness of the power transfer at lower cadence.
reviews.title: Great Smart Bike but Still Too Loud
